segment.source: Styles let you set control properties and reuse those settings for a consistent appearance across multiple controls.
segment.target: Styles let you set control properties and reuse those settings for a consistent appearance across multiple controls.

segment.source: Styling controls
segment.target: Styling controls

segment.source: Styling controls
segment.target: Styling controls

segment.source: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
segment.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

segment.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]
segment.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]

segment.source: You can customize the appearance of your apps in many ways by using the XAML framework.
segment.target: You can customize the appearance of your apps in many ways by using the XAML framework.

segment.source: Styles let you set control properties and reuse those settings for a consistent appearance across multiple controls.
segment.target: Styles let you set control properties and reuse those settings for a consistent appearance across multiple controls.

segment.source: Style basics
segment.target: Style basics

segment.source: Use styles to extract visual property settings into reusable resources.
segment.target: Use styles to extract visual property settings into reusable resources.

segment.source: Here's an example that shows 3 buttons with a style that sets the BorderBrush, BorderThickness and Foreground properties.
segment.target: Here's an example that shows 3 buttons with a style that sets the BorderBrush, BorderThickness and Foreground properties.

segment.source: By applying a style, you can make the controls appear the same without having to set these properties on each control separately.
segment.target: By applying a style, you can make the controls appear the same without having to set these properties on each control separately.

segment.source: styled buttons
segment.target: styled buttons

segment.source: You can define a style inline in the XAML for a control, or as a reusable resource.
segment.target: You can define a style inline in the XAML for a control, or as a reusable resource.

segment.source: Define resources in an individual page's XAML file, in the App.xaml file, or in a separate resource dictionary XAML file.
segment.target: Define resources in an individual page's XAML file, in the App.xaml file, or in a separate resource dictionary XAML file.

segment.source: A resource dictionary XAML file can be shared across apps, and more than one resource dictionary can be merged in a single app.
segment.target: A resource dictionary XAML file can be shared across apps, and more than one resource dictionary can be merged in a single app.

segment.source: Where the resource is defined determines the scope in which it can be used.
segment.target: Where the resource is defined determines the scope in which it can be used.

segment.source: Page-level resources are available only in the page where they are defined.
segment.target: Page-level resources are available only in the page where they are defined.

segment.source: If resources with the same key are defined in both App.xaml and in a page, the resource in the page overrides the resource in App.xaml.
segment.target: If resources with the same key are defined in both App.xaml and in a page, the resource in the page overrides the resource in App.xaml.

segment.source: If a resource is defined in a separate resource dictionary file, it's scope is determined by where the resource dictionary is referenced.
segment.target: If a resource is defined in a separate resource dictionary file, it's scope is determined by where the resource dictionary is referenced.

segment.source: In the Style definition, you need a TargetType attribute and a collection of one or more Setter elements.
segment.target: In the Style definition, you need a TargetType attribute and a collection of one or more Setter elements.

segment.source: The TargetType attribute is a string that specifies a FrameworkElement type to apply the style to.
segment.target: The TargetType attribute is a string that specifies a FrameworkElement type to apply the style to.

segment.source: The TargetType value must specify a FrameworkElement-derived type that's defined by the Windows Runtime or a custom type that's available in a referenced assembly.
segment.target: The TargetType value must specify a FrameworkElement-derived type that's defined by the Windows Runtime or a custom type that's available in a referenced assembly.

segment.source: If you try to apply a style to a control and the control's type doesn't match the TargetType attribute of the style you're trying to apply, an exception occurs.
segment.target: If you try to apply a style to a control and the control's type doesn't match the TargetType attribute of the style you're trying to apply, an exception occurs.

segment.source: Each Setter element requires a Property and a Value.
segment.target: Each Setter element requires a Property and a Value.

segment.source: These property settings indicate what control property the setting applies to, and the value to set for that property.
segment.target: These property settings indicate what control property the setting applies to, and the value to set for that property.

segment.source: You can set the Setter.Value with either attribute or property element syntax.
segment.target: You can set the Setter.Value with either attribute or property element syntax.

segment.source: The XAML here shows the style applied to the buttons shown previously.
segment.target: The XAML here shows the style applied to the buttons shown previously.

segment.source: In this XAML, the first two Setter elements use attribute syntax, but the last Setter, for the BorderBrush property, uses property element syntax.
segment.target: In this XAML, the first two Setter elements use attribute syntax, but the last Setter, for the BorderBrush property, uses property element syntax.

segment.source: The example doesn't use the x:Key attribute attribute, so the style is implicitly applied to the buttons.
segment.target: The example doesn't use the x:Key attribute attribute, so the style is implicitly applied to the buttons.

segment.source: Applying styles implicitly or explicitly is explained in the next section.
segment.target: Applying styles implicitly or explicitly is explained in the next section.

segment.source: Apply an implicit or explicit style
segment.target: Apply an implicit or explicit style

segment.source: If you define a style as a resource, there are two ways to apply it to your controls:
segment.target: If you define a style as a resource, there are two ways to apply it to your controls:

segment.source: Implicitly, by specifying only a TargetType for the Style.
segment.target: Implicitly, by specifying only a TargetType for the Style.

segment.source: Explicitly, by specifying a TargetType and an x:Key attribute attribute for the Style and then by setting the target control's Style property with a {StaticResource} markup extension reference that uses the explicit key.
segment.target: Explicitly, by specifying a TargetType and an x:Key attribute attribute for the Style and then by setting the target control's Style property with a {StaticResource} markup extension reference that uses the explicit key.

segment.source: If a style contains the x:Key attribute, you can only apply it to a control by setting the Style property of the control to the keyed style.
segment.target: If a style contains the x:Key attribute, you can only apply it to a control by setting the Style property of the control to the keyed style.

segment.source: In contrast, a style without an x:Key attribute is automatically applied to every control of its target type, that doesn't otherwise have an explicit style setting.
segment.target: In contrast, a style without an x:Key attribute is automatically applied to every control of its target type, that doesn't otherwise have an explicit style setting.

segment.source: Here are two buttons that demonstrate implicit and explicit styles.
segment.target: Here are two buttons that demonstrate implicit and explicit styles.

segment.source: implicitly and explicitly styled buttons.
segment.target: implicitly and explicitly styled buttons.

segment.source: In this example, the first style has an x:Key attribute and its target type is Button.
segment.target: In this example, the first style has an x:Key attribute and its target type is Button.

segment.source: The first button's Style property is set to this key, so this style is applied explicitly.
segment.target: The first button's Style property is set to this key, so this style is applied explicitly.

segment.source: The second style is applied implicitly to the second button because its target type is Button and the style doesn't have an x:Key attribute.
segment.target: The second style is applied implicitly to the second button because its target type is Button and the style doesn't have an x:Key attribute.

segment.source: Use based-on styles
segment.target: Use based-on styles

segment.source: To make styles easier to maintain and to optimize style reuse, you can create styles that inherit from other styles.
segment.target: To make styles easier to maintain and to optimize style reuse, you can create styles that inherit from other styles.

segment.source: You use the BasedOn property to create inherited styles.
segment.target: You use the BasedOn property to create inherited styles.

segment.source: Styles that inherit from other styles must target the same type of control or a control that derives from the type targeted by the base style.
segment.target: Styles that inherit from other styles must target the same type of control or a control that derives from the type targeted by the base style.

segment.source: For example, if a base style targets ContentControl, styles that are based on this style can target ContentControl or types that derive from ContentControl such as Button and ScrollViewer.
segment.target: For example, if a base style targets ContentControl, styles that are based on this style can target ContentControl or types that derive from ContentControl such as Button and ScrollViewer.

segment.source: If a value is not set in the based-on style, it's inherited from the base style.
segment.target: If a value is not set in the based-on style, it's inherited from the base style.

segment.source: To change a value from the base style, the based-on style overrides that value.
segment.target: To change a value from the base style, the based-on style overrides that value.

segment.source: The next example shows a Button and a CheckBox with styles that inherit from the same base style.
segment.target: The next example shows a Button and a CheckBox with styles that inherit from the same base style.

segment.source: styled buttons usign based-on styles.
segment.target: styled buttons usign based-on styles.

segment.source: The base style targets ContentControl, and sets the Height, and Width properties.
segment.target: The base style targets ContentControl, and sets the Height, and Width properties.

segment.source: The styles based on this style target CheckBox and Button, which derive from ContentControl.
segment.target: The styles based on this style target CheckBox and Button, which derive from ContentControl.

segment.source: The based-on styles set different colors for the BorderBrush and Foreground properties.
segment.target: The based-on styles set different colors for the BorderBrush and Foreground properties.

segment.source: (You don't typically put a border around a CheckBox.
segment.target: (You don't typically put a border around a CheckBox.

segment.source: We do it here to show the effects of the style.)
segment.target: We do it here to show the effects of the style.)

segment.source: Use tools to work with styles easily
segment.target: Use tools to work with styles easily

segment.source: A fast way to apply styles to your controls is to right-click on a control on the Microsoft Visual Studio XAML design surface and select Edit Style or Edit Template (depending on the control you are right-clicking on).
segment.target: A fast way to apply styles to your controls is to right-click on a control on the Microsoft Visual Studio XAML design surface and select Edit Style or Edit Template (depending on the control you are right-clicking on).

segment.source: You can then apply an existing style by selecting Apply Resource or define a new style by selecting Create Empty.
segment.target: You can then apply an existing style by selecting Apply Resource or define a new style by selecting Create Empty.

segment.source: If you create an empty style, you are given the option to define it in the page, in the App.xaml file, or in a separate resource dictionary.
segment.target: If you create an empty style, you are given the option to define it in the page, in the App.xaml file, or in a separate resource dictionary.

segment.source: Modify the default system styles
segment.target: Modify the default system styles

segment.source: You should use the styles that come from the Windows Runtime default XAML resources when you can.
segment.target: You should use the styles that come from the Windows Runtime default XAML resources when you can.

segment.source: When you have to define your own styles, try to base your styles on the default ones when possible (using based-on styles as explained earlier, or start by editing a copy of the original default style).
segment.target: When you have to define your own styles, try to base your styles on the default ones when possible (using based-on styles as explained earlier, or start by editing a copy of the original default style).

segment.source: The Template property
segment.target: The Template property

segment.source: A style setter can be used for the Template property of a Control, and in fact this makes up the majority of a typical XAML style and an app's XAML resources.
segment.target: A style setter can be used for the Template property of a Control, and in fact this makes up the majority of a typical XAML style and an app's XAML resources.

segment.source: This is discussed in more detail in the topic Control templates.
segment.target: This is discussed in more detail in the topic Control templates.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: This article is for Windows 10 developers writing Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps.
segment.target: This article is for Windows 10 developers writing Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps.

segment.source: If you’re developing for Windows 8.x or Windows Phone 8.x, see the archived documentation.
segment.target: If you’re developing for Windows 8.x or Windows Phone 8.x, see the archived documentation.
